Award.AwardTitle: Scaling up nonconsumptive effects of predators: mechanisms driving dynamics over multi-generational time scales in complex communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding predator-prey interactions is essential to the stewardship of ecosystems. For example, invasive predators cause widespread ecological problems, and other invasive species (plants, animals and microbes) may influence predator-prey interactions. Typically the ecological consequences of predators are envisioned as the direct effects of killing prey. Ecologists are, however, becoming increasingly aware of the importance of non-consumptive effects of predators, which result from prey behaviors to avoid being killed by predators. For example, when predator density increases, prey may change their use of habitat, hide more, and eat less. Behavioral responses to avoid predation are hypothesized to cost the prey's fitness and may affect the prey population as much as direct mortality from predation. These effects may then cascade to affect other species in the ecosystem. A number of short-term studies have demonstrated that such non-consumptive effects can affect prey growth rate and death rate in diverse ecosystems. This study is designed to scale up our understanding of non-consumptive effects in real communities on longer time scales, in order to investigate the influence of non-consumptive effects on prey abundance and ecological community structure. The investigators will use a combination of theoretical and experimental approaches based on a model fish-zooplankton community, to identify and elucidate non-consumptive effects of predators that are not predicted to arise from direct effects of predators killing prey.

Non-consumptive effects arise from a process common to all ecosystems and therefore this research will elucidate concepts and approaches that are of general relevance, thereby benefiting the management and stewardship of diverse ecosystems. In addition to supporting the research training and mentoring of two graduate students, this project will provide research experiences for a large number of undergraduate students. The project also involves outreach to present results to state agencies and citizen groups, and to develop demonstration modules on lake ecosystems and basic ecological concepts and issues for presentation to K-12 classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Predators can strongly affect their prey, and thus predator-prey interactions have a large impact on ecological communities.  The focus on predator effects is typically on the effects they have through eating prey which reduces prey numbers.  However, prey display large changes in their behavior when there are more predators in the environment.  These changes in behavior extend much further than simply escaping from an attacking predator: if prey sense predators in their vicinity, prey may spend much less time eating and more time watching for predators, or change the habitat they use altogether. If they are eating less, or are in a poorer habitat, it is possible such behavioral responses can affect density. Thus in addition to killing prey, predators affect prey abundance in this second way through their presence changing prey behavior.  But is the behavior response effect on prey density large compared to the effects predators have through eating the prey? In other words, does this effect matter?

We looked at this question in experimental systems with fish and insect predators, and with many different zooplankton (small aquatic invertebrate) prey species.  We showed that fish in cages, in which their scent emanated into large tanks, had large effects on the zooplankton behavior in that some zooplankton species changed their location in the tank when fish were present. Whereas most zooplankton moved lower in the tanks and closer to the tank sides if predators were in the tank, different species varied in their response and some even moved in the opposite direction.  We also found that fish presence affected zooplankton density, but not always in the negative (predicted) direction, but rather positively. One might expect that the prey species that are the most susceptible to predation would be the species that has the largest behavioral response.  One might also expect that the zooplankton species that have the largest behavioral response to fish would be the species whose abundance is most negatively affected. Interestingly, we found both of these intuitive expectations did not hold in our experiments.  This finding highlights underlying processes that add complexity to the influence of a prey’s prey behavioral responses to predators.

Many different people were trained on this project, including a graduate student and 23 undergraduate students.  Three undergraduate students were trained in presenting scientific research, and did so at a research forum.  The project facilitated outreach through K-5 classroom presentations of aquatic ecology concepts, including the large role zooplankton play in ponds and lakes.  Other broader impact activities, connected with the project, included engaging K-12 students in a number of venues including at Michigan State University’s “Grandparents University” and to students in the Green Adventures Camp from Ann Arbor Public Schools (with 40 underrepresented students ages 5-12). Further, students from this project gave presentations to undergraduate students from Eastern Michigan University and the University of Michigan about the ecological processes examined in this project and in experimental design concepts.
